Metamorphic conditions estimated for the garnet felsic granulite sample VAB01 using the
THERMOCALC average P–T calculations suggest ultra-high temperatures of 1009 ± 72 °C at
pressures of 11.5 ± 1.5 kbar. The Pattison et al. (2003) thermobarometer yielded similar
temperatures (1020 °C), but significantly higher pressures (14.4 kbar). However, at a fixed
pressure of 11 bar, temperatures of 936 °C are calculated, within uncertainties of the
THERMOCALC calculations.
Calculated conditions for the garnet mafic granulite are similar to those for the garnet
felsic granulite. The THERMOCALC calculations yielded 936 ± 93 °C at 10.2 ± 1.1 kbar, whereas
the Al-solubility-based thermobarometer yielded a temperature of 919 °C and pressure of 11.0
kbar.
Phase Equilibria Modelling
The P–T pseudosection for garnet felsic granulite VAB01 is shown in Figure 5. Within the
P–T window, the solidus occurs between 840 and 880 °C, from low to high P. Orthopyroxene is
77
stable at relatively low P, and garnet at relatively high P, with both minerals coexisting within a
broad field at pressures of 8 – 12 kbar. Clinopyroxene is not stable at the highest pressures and
low temperatures, but otherwise is stable with all other phases in several combinations. The
hornblende-out line is strongly dependent on temperature, its stability ranging from ~860 °C at 7
kbar to 930 °C at 13 kbar. Magnetite is only stable at low pressures (<8–10 kbar). K-feldspar
stability is predicted up to temperatures of 960 (low P) and 1040 °C (high P). Quartz, plagioclase
and ilmenite are present throughout the calculated window, and biotite is not predicted to be
stable. The field that contains the inferred peak paragenesis, clinopyroxene–orthopyroxene–
garnet–ilmenite–K-feldspar–plagioclase–quartz–melt is predicted to be stable between 880 and
1030 °C at 8.6 to 12.1 kbar. The quantity of melt in this field varies from 5 to 20 mol.% (Figure 5).
Figure 5. Calculated P–T pseudosection for the bulk composition of VAB01, a garnet felsic granulite, using the augite model for clinopyroxene. Contours show the modal proportion of melt (dashed lines), and the solidus is represented by a bold red line.
The changing modal proportion of phases as a function of temperature was calculated at
a fixed pressure of 10 kbar (Figure 6). At these conditions, the onset of partial melting occurs
around 875 °C, at which point the rock contains 15% hornblende. With increasing temperature,
the proportion of melt increases rapidly and the quantity of hornblende decreases until it
disappears at 925 °C. The quantity of K-feldspar remains relatively constant (~ 10%) until
hornblende is exhausted, thereafter it decreases and disappears around 1000 °C. The amount of
78
garnet remains constant (~ 8%) prior to the onset of partial melting, thereafter increasing (up to
13%) until the consumption of hornblende when the abundance of garnet decreases until it is
exhausted around 1000 °C. The appearance of clinopyroxene broadly coincides with the onset of
melting at this pressure, increasing to 4% as hornblende is consumed. Orthopyroxene appears at
900 °C during hornblende breakdown, reaching an abundance of 7%. The proportion of quartz
remains constant until the onset of partial melting (around 27%), decreasing slightly towards
higher temperatures (18% at 1050 °C). After the onset of the partial melting, plagioclase increases
in abundance from 33% up to 38%, thereafter decreasing following the prograde exhaustion of K-
feldspar and garnet (Figure 6). At the maximum modelled temperature (1050 °C), the melt
fraction has reached ~35%.
Figure 6. Calculated changes in modal proportions of phases at 10 kbar for sample VAB01, a garnet felsic granulite.
The variation of melt composition (in weight %) at fixed pressure (10 kbar) has also been
calculated (Figure 7). At lower temperatures, the H2O content in the melt is 3% decreasing to<1%
at 1050 °C, while the content of FeO + MgO increases from 2.5% at 850 °C to 8% at 1050 °C. As
temperature increases, K2O + Na2O decreases from 8% to 6%, while CaO increases from 2% to
4%. The SiO2 content decreases towards higher temperature from 66% to 63% and Al2O3 contents
remain constant.
79
Figure 7. Calculated melt composition at 10 kbar. The modal proportion of the melt is indicated with a non-linear scale (*) at the top of the figure.
The P–T pseudosection for the garnet mafic granulite with 1% H2O is shown in Figure 8A.
The solidus has a positive slope but switches to negative at pressures above the disappearance of
orthopyroxene, at around 9 kbar and between 830 and 880 °C. The hornblende-out line is broadly
parallel to the solidus but occurs at higher temperatures, between 870 and 900 °C. Magnetite,
garnet and orthopyroxene stabilities are strongly dependent on pressure. Magnetite and
orthopyroxene are stable at lower pressures, magnetite below 8.2–9.4 kbar and orthopyroxene
below 8.1–10.4 kbar. Garnet is predicted at higher pressures, above 7.6–9.8 kbar. Where
hornblende is present also is quartz in the pseudosection, whereas in the hornblende-free region
quartz is absent at pressures below ~9.5 kbar. Rutile occurs only at pressures above 12 kbar.
Plagioclase, clinopyroxene and ilmenite are present throughout the P–T range considered. The
paragenesis quartz–garnet–ilmenite–orthopyroxene–clinopyroxene–plagioclase–leucosome,
interpreted to have been present at the metamorphic peak, is calculated to occur between 900
and 1030 °C, at pressures of 9 to 10.4 kbar, within a field no wider than 0.5 kbar. The modal
proportion of melt calculated within this field varies from 5 to 20% (Figure 8A).
80
Figure 8. Calculated P–T pseudosection for a garnet-bearing garnet mafic granulite (PAR03), using an augite model for clinopyroxene. (A) Water content around 1 mol. %. (B) Water content of 0.01 mol. %. Contours for the modal proportion of melt are shown with dashed lines, and the solidus is represented by a bold red line.
The P–T pseudosection for the garnet mafic granulite with minimal water (Figure 8B; H2O
~ 0.01%) presents similarities with the one calculated for 1 mol.% H2O. However, the solidus and
hornblende-out lines coincide and occur at higher temperatures of between 860 and 900 °C.
Garnet is stable at pressures above 7.4 kbar and orthopyroxene is stable at pressures below 8.8–
10.7 kbar. Magnetite and rutile do not occur in the P–T window considered. Plagioclase,
clinopyroxene and ilmenite are present throughout, and quartz is stable at all P–T conditions,
except the lowest ones. The peak paragenesis occurs at temperatures above 880 °C and at
pressures between 8 and 10.7 kbar, for which melt modal proportions are<1% (Figure 8B).
Zircon U-Pb Geochronology
Samples VAB01 and VAB19 both contain two types of zircon crystals with different shapes
and internal CL domains (Figure 9). One type comprises subhedral prismatic crystals (~2:1 length
to width aspect ratio) with rounded terminations, and dark luminescent cores with narrow to
broad oscillatory-zoning, surrounded by bright-CL rims that are homogeneous or have sector-
zoning. This zircon type yielded 206Pb/238U dates ranging from c. 631 to 705 Ma (Figure 10A). In
both samples, the cores have similar Th/U ratios with an average value of 0.6 and contents of U
and Th that are always higher than 100 ppm (Figure 10C). A second group of crystals is rounded
and shows sector zoning (‘soccer ball’), with bright to moderate CL response, occasionally with
darker xenocrystic oscillatory-zoned cores (Figure 9). These bright CL rims and the soccer ball
crystals appear to belong to the same age population and yielded weighted mean 206Pb/238U dates
of 593.8 ± 8.5 Ma in VAB01 and 598.5 ±4.6 Ma in VAB19 (Figure 10A and B). Their Th/U ratios are
81
higher than the oscillatory-zoned cores and are often >1.0 (Figure 10C). This group is variably
depleted in U compared to the first zircon type and can also be depleted in Th (Figure 10C).
Figure 9. CL images for representative zircon crystals from the three studied samples. Yellow ellipses show the location of SHRIMP spots (~ 20 µm diameter) and blue circles the location of LASS-ICP-MS spots (~ 50 µm diameter). Labels present spot ID, 206Pb/238U date (Ma), U content (ppm) and ?Hf(t) values, when the latter is available. Labels in yellow show SHRIMP data, while labels in blue LASS-ICP-MS data. (A) Sample VAB01, oscillatory-zoned cores show older ages and higher U than soccer ball crystals. (B) Sample VAB19, oscillatory-zoned cores show older ages and higher U than rims and soccer ball crystals. (C) Sample RGM55, broad oscillatory- and sector zoned cores show the oldest ages, ghost oscillatory- and sector- zoned cores older than rims and soccer ball crystals. Uncertainties are 1?.
Sample RGM55 contains three morphological types of zircon crystal (Figure 9). These
include subhedral prismatic grains with rounded terminations, which are similar to those in
VAB01 and VAB19, but with cores that are predominantly sector-zoned with only a few grains
exhibiting broad-oscillatory patterns, and rims that are darkly luminescent with relatively high U,
rather than bright-CL and low-U. Soccer ball zircons are also present, but have a darker CL
82
response and higher U content than those in VAB01 and VAB19 (Figure 10C). A third group
comprises anhedral zircon grains with sector-zoning. In this sample, the prismatic sector-zoned
cores yielded a weighted mean 206Pb/238U date of 624.8 ± 3.4 Ma (Figure 10D) with Th/U ratio of
0.56 (Figure 10C), although one spot from a broad oscillatory-zoned core yielded an older
206Pb/238U date of 639 ± 9 Ma (1? error). Complementary U-Pb data obtained by LASS-ICP-MS in
grains with broad oscillatory-zoned or some sector-zoned revealed oldest 206Pb/238U dates
scattered from 631.4 ± 8.5 to 660.9 ± 7.1 Ma (Figure 10F) and the Th/U ratio is similar to the last
group (Figure 10C). The rims, soccer ball and anhedral grains have lower Th/U ratios (0.26 –
Figure 10C), with depleted Th contents relative to sector-zone cores and yielded a younger
weighted mean 206Pb/238U date of 615.8 ± 3.4 Ma (Figure 10E), although two spots, rejected from
this weighted mean age calculation, yielded younger 206Pb/238U dates of 599 ± 8 Ma and 594 ± 7
Ma (1? error).
Figure 10. Concordia diagrams with zircon U–Pb isotopic data collected with SHRIMP II (2? error ellipses) in (A), (B), (D) and (E), in which: (A) Data for sample VAB01 from soccer ball zircon (sb) and rims with a weighted mean 206Pb/238U age of 593.8 ± 8.5 Ma and cores ranging up to c. 700 Ma. (B) Data for sample VAB19 from soccer ball zircon and rims with a weighted mean 206Pb/238U age of 598 ± 4.6 Ma and cores ranging up to c. 700 Ma. (D) Zircon cores from sample RGM55 with a weighted mean 206Pb/238U age of 624.8 ± 3.4 Ma. (E) Soccer ball and shapeless zircon and rims from sample RGM55 with a weighted mean 206Pb/238U age of 615.8 ± 3.4 Ma. Contents of Th and U of different zircon types are shown in (C), in which: 1 – oscillatory-zoned cores from VAB01; 2 – rims and soccer ball crystals from VAB01; 3 – oscillatory-zoned cores from VAB19; 4 – rims and soccer ball crystals from VAB19; 5 – older broad oscillatory-zoned or sector-zoned cores from RGM55, obtained by LASS-ICP-MS; 6 – 625 Ma sector-zoned core from RGM55; and 7 – 615 Ma high U domain from RGM55. (F) Histogram of older dates found with complementary U-Pb data by LASS-ICP-MS for sample RGM55.
REE and Lu-Hf in zircon
The same samples analyzed with the SHRIMP were analyzed for REE abundances and
Lu0Hf isotopes by LASS-ICP-MS (VAB01, VAB19 and RGM55). The analyses were made in the five
different zircon domains differentiated on the basis of CL and U-Pb analysis: (i) oscillatory-zoned
83
cores (VAB01 and VAB19), (ii) sector-zoned to broad oscillatory-zoned crystals (RGM55), (iii)
sector-zoned cores (RGM55), (iv) soccer ball crystals and rims with high U (RGM55) and (v) soccer
ball crystals and rims with low U (VAB01 and VAB19).
Sample VAB01 shows three distinct patterns of zircon REE distribution (Figure 11A). The
oscillatory-zoned cores, which yielded the oldest dates up to c. 705 Ma, have moderately enriched
in LREE relative to chondrite, with weak or no Eu anomalies and strongly enriched in HREE, up to
10,000 times more than chondrite (Figure 11A). The 176Hf/177Hf ratios are concentrated between
0.282223 and 0.282251 (Figure 11F), which yielded ?Hf(t) between -4.73 and -4.11, with an outlier
value of 0.282325 (?Hf(t) = -0.87). The zircon rims are depleted in La with a pronounced positive
Ce anomaly and a weakly negative Eu anomaly, and a steeper HREE array, although the
enrichment in HREE content are lower than the oscillatoy-zoned cores (Figure 11A). The soccer
ball crystals, which yielded the same ages as the rims (c. 595), present the same pattern of LREE
and MREE than the rims, however, the HREE array is flat or exhibits a slightly enrichment (Figure
11A). Zircon rims and soccer ball grains have similar 176Hf/177Hf ratios, between 0.282245 and
0.282314 (Figure 11F), with ?Hf(t) between -6.02 and -3.31.
Figure 11. Zircon REE chondrite-normalized pattern (Sun and McDonough, 1989) in (A) to (E), in which: (A) VAB01; (B) VAB19; (C) Older spot ages from RGM55; (D) 625 Ma sector-zoned cores from RGM55; (E) 615 Ma high-U domains in RGM55. (F) 176Hf/177Hf against 206Pb/238U for different zircon types, in which: 1 – oscillatory-zoned cores from VAB01; 2 – soccer ball crystals from VAB01. 3 – rims from VAB01; 4 – oscillatory-zoned cores from VAB19; 5 – soccer ball crystals from VAB19; 6 – rim from VAB19; 7 – older domain from RGM55; 8 – 625 Ma sector-zoned cores from RGM55; 9 – 615 Ma high- U domains from RGM55.
Zircon from sample VAB19 shows similarities with zircon from VAB01 (Figure 11B).
Oscillatory-zoned cores (up to c. 700 Ma) exhibit a moderately enriched in L- and MREE, with no
Eu anomalies and a strongly enriched in HREE (Figure 11B). The 176Hf/177Hf ratios of this group
are similar to the zircon oscillatory-zoned cores from sample VAB01, with ?Hf(t) between -4.04
and -4.02 (Figure 11F). A single analysis from a rim shows a strongly enriched pattern in LREE,
84
higher than the oscillatory-zoned cores, and in HREE, lower than the oscillatory-zoned cores, with
a negative Eu anomaly (Figure 11B). This rim yielded the lowest 176Hf/177Hf value of 0.281962
(Figure 11F), hence the most negative ?Hf(t) (-15.9). Soccer ball crystals, which yielded the same
age as the rim (c. 600 Ma), show the same pattern as soccer ball grains from VAB01, with depletion
in La, strongly positive Ce anomalies, weakly negative Eu anomalies and flat distribution of HREE
(Figure 11B). The 176Hf/177Hf ratios are slightly higher than the oscillatory-zoned cores, between
0.282254 and 0.282271 (Figure 11F) and ?Hf(t) between -5.92 and -4.12.
In sample RGM55, the sector-zoned to broad oscillatory-zoned domains, which ranging
from 631 and 661 Ma, present both enrichment and depletion in LREE, with weakly to strongly
positive Ce anomalies and negative Eu anomalies (Figure 11C). There are an enriched pattern in
HREE. Zircon crystals from this sample are less radiogenic than the ones from the other samples
(VAB01 and VAB19). In this domain, they show a 176Hf/177Hf ratios between 0.282148 and
0.282207 and the ?Hf(t) ranges from -8.48 and -6.36 (Figure 11F).
The prismatic crystals from RGM55 with sector-zoned cores and dates of c. 625 Ma shows
two different pattern of LREE: one with moderately enriched and weakly positive Ce anomalies
and another depleted in LREE with strongly positive Ce anomalies. M- and HREE distribution are
similar and present negative Eu anomalies and strong enrichment in the heaviest elements
(Figure 11D). The 176Hf/177Hf ratios range from 0.282150 and 0.282181 (Figure 11F) and the ?Hf(t)
from -8.55 and -7.34.
The REE array in the anhedral and soccer ball grains from sample RGM55 (c. 615 Ma)
shows spread in LREE distribution with a positive Ce anomaly less pronounced than the sector-
zoned cores, although an outlier spot is enriched in LREE without Ce anomaly (Figure 11E). The
MREE shows negative Eu anomalies and, as the other domains in this sample, there are a steeper
enrichment in HREE. The 176Hf/177Hf ratios, between 0.282133 and 0.282201, and ?Hf(t), between
-9.71 and -7.04, are similar to the other domains (Figure 11F).
DISCUSSION
P–T path
The metamorphic P–T path of the base of Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe can be constraint with
sample VAB01 due to its particular petrographic features. Biotite grains armored in garnet have
rounded shapes, high Ti content and XMg. Therefore, the earliest stages of the partial melting may
have been by reactions consuming biotite as the hydrous mineral. Nevertheless, to reach the UHT
conditions and preserve mineral assemblages, the rock is likely to have become depleted in these
first batches of melt (Clark et al., 2011; Kelsey and Hand, 2015; Vielzeuf et al., 1990), and hence
less prone to thermal buffering. Thus, the metamorphic modelling here calculated cannot reflect
85
the prograde composition and metamorphic path that the granulites were subjected. However,
the metamorphic peak and the retrograde path can be constraint by the pseudosection.
According to the thermodynamic models presented here, melting was driven by
breakdown of K-feldspar and garnet once the rock was exhausted of hydrous minerals (Figure 6).
The granulite is extremely depleted in Th and U, which highlight the melt loss added with the
depletion in Rb and Y (Figure 3). A small enrichment in Sr and Ti suggests that plagioclase and Ti
phases were not involved in intensive way as partial melting reactants (Figure 3).
The calculated pseudosection assemblage fields for the inferred metamorphic paragenesis
in both the garnet felsic and mafic granulites overlap and are consistent with peak conditions of
around 1000 °C at pressures higher than 9 kbar (Figure 12). Calculations using the average P–T
mode of THERMOCALC yielded similar conditions, coincident with P–T estimates based on the
maximum Al-in-orthopyroxene of the garnet felsic granulite (Figure 12).
Figure 12. Summary of P–T-t estimates for rocks of the Guaxupé Domain. Peak fields for samples VAB01 (felsic granulite) and PAR03 (mafic granulite) are overlain to show the region of overlap. AlT isopleth in orthopyroxene is at similar conditions to those calculated in the average P–T mode of THERMOCALC. The post-peak evolution leads to the magnetite growth coexisting with garnet, this moment coincides with the crystallization of high U rims and the formation of xenomorphic and soccer ball zircon at c. 615 Ma. The end of the crystallization of the melt happened at 870 °C and 8.5 kbar and it is marked by the crystallization of low U rims and soccer ball zircon depleted in HREE at c. 595 Ma. The prograde evolution is dashed because the uncertainties around the protolith, and partial melt and melt segregation mean that the present-day bulk composition may not be representative of previous conditions, although sector-zoned zircon grains are representative of this period at c. 625 Ma.
86
The retrograde P-T path started with a small decrease in pressure to 9 kbar (Figure 12),
by a discrete orthopyroxene replacing garnet and in which magnetite was exsolved from ilmenite
(Figure 2). At this point, the rock followed a near-isobaric-cooling path, in the stability field of
garnet, since coronas or other textures of garnet replacement are rare, and when present poorly
developed. Clinopyroxene formed a partial corona at rims of orthopyroxene and the same feature
is observed in the garnet mafic granulite. At temperatures close to the solidus, hornblende began
to crystallize at the edge of pyroxene, particularly in leucosome, at 870 °C and 8.5 kbar (Figure
12).
Metamorphic timescales
The geochronologic data obtained reveal at least four groups of ages that can be related to
distinct periods of zircon crystallization: one related to early-orogenic magmatism, one related to
prograde to peak metamorphism and two related to the melt crystallization (Figure 12). Although
the garnet felsic granulite and the diatexite appear not to have the same protolith some
comparison can be done.
In samples VAB01 and VAB19, zircon crystals with oscillatory-zoned cores exhibit higher
U and lower Th/U ratio than their rims or soccer ball crystals (Figure 10C), and they also display
older dates, ranging from c. 630 Ma up to 705 Ma. In a zircon/garnet REE partitioning diagram,
this domain, in sample VAB01, zircon has higher concentration of LREE and HREE, and similar
contents of MREE than any garnet domain (Figure 13A, C and E). Conversely, in sample VAB19
this domain is just enriched in LREE and depleted in M and HREE related to garnet (Figure 13G).
However, a novel approach using an array plot of log (DYb/DGd) vs. log (DYb) of every zircon
analyses against all different garnet compositions has been proved to deal better with the
zircon/garnet equilibrium (Taylor et al., 2017). Thus, no matter how garnet compositional domain
is used, zircon cores from VAB01 did not grow in equilibrium with garnet because it shows a
negative slope array (Figure 13B, D and F), which is the opposite that is observed in experimental
data equilibrium for the pair (Rubatto and Hermann, 2007; Taylor et al., 2015). This domain in
sample VAB19, although exhibits a positive slope in the array diagram, shows a displacement from
the experiments (Figure 13H), therefore, these zircon cores were not in equilibrium with garnet.
Sample RGM55 also shows older ages scattered from c. 631 to 660 Ma in oscillatory-zoned
or sector-zoned cores of zircon, although they have distinct REE and Hf signatures. Thereby, these
oldest dates from the three samples may reflect the age of igneous crystallization of the protolith
and do not have relation to the metamorphism, as observed in others studies (Janasi, 2002, 1999;
Martins et al., 2009; Mora et al., 2014; Rocha et al., 2018, 2017; Tedeschi et al., 2018).
87
Figure 13. Zircon and garnet trace elements data from garnet felsic granulite (VAB01 and VAB19). Tradicional DREE (zircon–garnet) plot in (A), (C), (E) and (G). Array plot, purposed by Taylor et al. (2017), showing DREE (zircon–garnet) for all zircon against average garnet domains in (B), (D), (F) and (H). (A) and (B) zircon data plotted against garnet cores depleted in HREE from sample VAB01(core 1 from Figure 4B). (C) and (D) zircon data plotted against cores/intermediate portion of garnet from sample VAB01 (core 2 from Figure 4B). (E) and (F) zircon data plotted against garnet rims from sample VAB01 (rim from Figure 4B). (G) and (H) zircon data plotted against the single garnet domain from sample VAB19 (Figure 4D). (*) zircon–garnet data from Taylor et al. (2015) performed at 7 kbar. (**)zircon–garnet data from (Rubatto and Hermann (2007) performed at 20 kbar.
In the diatexite (RGM55) subhedral prismatic zircon with sector-zoned cores record a
weighted mean date of 625.9 ± 3.5 Ma. Based on its bulk REE pattern (enriched in LREE),
mineralogy (allanite-bearing and garnet-depleted), and REE pattern in zircon (with pronounced
positive Ce and negative Eu anomalies), this sample may not have the same protolith as the garnet
felsic granulite. Thus, this date of c. 625 Ma may represent the age of protolith crystallization,
although a previously mentioned oscillatory-zoned core yields older date (> 630 Ma). Another
possibility is that the c. 625 Ma date could represent recrystallization of inherited material, since
88
this process can result in expulsion of the pre-existing Pb, and resetting of the U-Pb system (Taylor
et al., 2016). Grains of this domain show a progressive loss of the original internal features, which
is commonly observed in high-grade conditions (Taylor et al., 2016), as can be observed in grain
#3 (SHRIMP analysis) in Figure 9C that shows a ghost of oscillatory-zoned texture,. This age
matches the timing of the metamorphic peak in the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe as determined in
other studies (Rocha et al., 2018, 2017; Tedeschi et al., 2018).
The rims of most zircon crystals, soccer ball and shapeless zircon crystals in sample
RGM55 register the highest contents in U (up to 347 ppm) and lowest Th/U ratios (~ 0.23) of the
studied samples (Figure 10C). They yield a date of 615.8 ± 3.4 Ma, which represents the age of the
onset of melt crystallization (Figure 12), since the dissolution of previously crystallized zircon
may, at the first stage, provide high U contents to the melt (Watson and Harrison, 1983;
Yakymchuk et al., 2018). In comparison to their cores, they are depleted in Th and have a wider
variable of LREE contents, suggesting that allanite, a sink for these elements (Hermann, 2002) had
also started to crystallize from the melt. This was made possible by the very high abundance of
LREE in the bulk composition which will stabilize allanite at such high temperature conditions
(Hermann, 2002). Similar ages are also interpreted as the time of melt crystallization in other
studies from rocks of the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe (Martins et al., 2009; Mora et al., 2014; Rocha,
2016; Rocha et al., 2017).
The rims and soccer ball zircon from samples VAB01 and VAB19 record the lowest
contents of U, the highest Th/U ratios and the youngest ages (Figure 10C). Major phases are more
able to incorporate U rather than Th (Yakymchuk et al., 2018), thus, without the presence of a Th-
bearing phase, the Th/U ratios in the melt tend to increase during crystallization. Therefore, this
group may reflect the final crystallization of the trapped melt (Figure 12), when the availability of
U was low.
The DREE for zircon–garnet from sample VAB01 for soccer ball crystals shows a flat pattern
of MREE and HREE (Figure 13C and E), excepted if they were normalized to the core of larger
garnet grains (Figure 13A). Other than that, the data from zircon rims show flat pattern of MREE
and enrichment in HREE (Figure 13A, C and E). However, in the array plot zircon, although all
zircon data show the same positive slope than the experimental data, they are detached from them
if compared to this garnet domain (Figure 13B), thus, they were not in equilibrium. The garnet
cores from smaller crystals or the intermediate domain of larger crystals and the garnet rims from
sample VAB01 fit better the zircon data, which show the same slope and trends than the
experimental data (Figure 13D and F), suggesting that they were in equilibrium. A small variation
in the garnet composition between cores and rims indicates they were homogenized by the high-
grade metamorphic conditions (Figure 4). The zircon rims are more suitable with the high
89
pressure experimental data from Rubatto and Hermann (2007), whereas the array of soccer ball
crystals fits better with the lower pressure experimental data from Taylor et al. (2015). Although,
zircon rims and soccer ball crystals yielded the same dates (c. 595 Ma), zircon rims could be
crystallized earlier at higher pressures, taking advantage of pre-existing crystals, than the truly
metamorphic zircon grains, the soccer ball ones. Thus, this behaviour implies that the low U zircon
group from VAB01 grew in equilibrium with garnet, which is supported by the flat pattern of HREE
in both minerals (Figure 4 and Figure 11), once both were competing to these elements.
Zircon rims and soccer ball crystals DREE for zircon–garnet plot from sample VAB19 show
M and HREE depleted in comparison with garnet, although the analyzed rims show the same
pattern as their cores (Figure 13G). However, as seen in the array plot (Figure 13H), the data are
displaced from the experimental data, which indicates that zircon and garnet were not in
equilibrium. In this case, garnet may be crystallized earlier than zircon, since it shows an enriched
pattern in HREE (Figure 4), while zircon shows a flat HREE pattern (Figure 11). HREE is strongly
partitioned into garnet (Chen et al., 2010), thus garnet had already sequestered HREE when zircon
was crystallized.
The isobaric-cooling path earlier discussed shows that the garnet modal proportion
increases toward low temperature, as predicted in the pseudosection modelling (Figure 6). It is
likely that the date printed in the low U zircon group from VAB01 and VAB19, c. 595-600 Ma,
represents the age of late trapped melt crystallization. Therefore, with the onset melting
crystallization at c. 615 Ma, the duration of melt crystallization is inferred to last for c. 20 Myr
(Figure 12).
Contribution to the regional tectonic framework
Calculated P-T conditions predicted UHT metamorphic conditions for all three samples,
which are localized thirty kilometers apart from each other. Consistent T values higher than 900
°C are calculated with several methods at pressures higher than 10 kbar at the base of Socorro
Guaxupé Nappe. These UHT conditions have also been observed in other rocks associated with
the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe (e.g. Del Lama et al., 2000; Rocha et al., 2017). Extensive and
associated charnockite magmatism is found in the area, with magmas generated at temperatures
higher than 900 °C (Janasi, 2002; Mora et al., 2014). Therefore, it is likely that the UHT conditions
were widespread within the orogen, although a diagnostic UHT mineral association has never
been recognized.
The Guaxupé Domain is composed of different sorts of protoliths, including pelites, mafic
and felsic igneous rocks, with felsic igneous rocks being the most voluminous. The magmatism
crystallization ages seem to be slightly younger than the metamorphic event (Campos Neto et al.,
90
1996; Campos Neto and Caby, 2000; Mora et al., 2014; Rocha, 2016; Rocha et al., 2017; Tedeschi,
2018). However, recently zircons of Neoarchean to Paleoproterozoic age were dated in residue
and leucosome of the basal granulites (Tedeschi, 2018; Tedeschi et al., 2018).
In this work, the inherited cores of analyzed zircon crystals from garnet felsic granulite
(VAB01 and VAB19) have dates between 630 and 705 Ma and their REE pattern is characterized
by relative enrichment in LREE and strong enrichment in HREE, which generally is different from
patterns of other identified zircon groups. In discrimination diagrams proposed by Belousova et
al. (2002), their composition is consistent to that of zircon crystallizing in igneous rocks of TTG
affinity. Zircon crystals of a diatexite (RGM55) also show older ages scattered between 630 and
660 Ma and may reflect inherited ages, although their REE patterns and Hf signatures are different
from the garnet felsic granulite. These dates suggest a protracted magmatic event, lasting c. 85
Myr, although they could also indicate variable Pb loss along the Concordia from a single
population of c. 705 Ma magmatic zircon during UHT metamorphism. Many authors advocate that
these cores are related to the generation of a pre-collisional magmatic arc (e.g. Campos Neto et al.,
1996; Campos Neto and Caby, 2000; Mora et al., 2014). However, in this study, their Hf signatures
show a crustal source for the magmas. Actually, there are no data with juvenile signatures, and
probably these rocks were intruded and reworked older continental crust, as indicated by the
negative ?Hf(t) values.
The ages of c. 625 Ma, related to the prograde path, and c. 615 Ma, related to the onset of
melt crystallization, bracket the age of the metamorphic peak. A scenario with a protracted high-
grade event and an isobaric-cooling path is extensively discussed in literature (e.g. Clark et al.,
2015; Harley, 2008; Kelsey and Hand, 2015; Korhonen et al., 2013; Laurent et al., 2018), and seems
to fit well with the Guaxupé Domain.
CONCLUSIONS
In the southernmost portion of Brasília Orogen, a stack of nappes from Guaxupé Domain
underwent UHT conditions with peak metamorphism at 1000 °C and 11.5 kbar. Hydrated phases
were not part of the partial melt reactions at the metamorphic peak, and instead it seems
breakdown of K-feldspar and garnet played an important role in melt generation at the highest
temperatures. These conditions were preceded by recrystallization of inherited zircon at c. 625
Ma. A stage of decompression from the peak conditions to 9 kbar was followed by crystallization
of melt and high-U zircon grains and rims at c. 615 Ma. A final period of melt crystallization
occurred at 870 °C at 8.5 kbar in a field where magnetite and garnet were crystallizing and is
marked by soccer ball zircon crystals and rims depleted in U and HREE.
91
This evolution defines a clockwise P–T path with a short period of decompression that is
younger than 625 Ma but no older than 615 Ma, followed by a long period of near isobaric-cooling
until 595 Ma, suggesting that the lower crust was heated to high-grade conditions for at least 30
Myr and that the crystallization of partial melt lasted 20 Myr.

ANEXO II – THE ORIGIN OF CHARNOCKITES FROM GRANULITE
PARTIAL MELTING: AN EXAMPLE IN THE SOCORRO-GUAXUPÉ NAPPE,
SOUTHEASTERN BRAZIL
Manuscrito que será submetido ao periódico Precambrian Research
100
The origin of charnockites from granulite partial melting: an example
in the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe, southeastern Brazil
Rafael Gonçalves Motta a b
rafagmotta@gmail.com
Renato Moraes c
rmoraes@usp.br
Ian C. W. Fitzsimons b
i.fitzsimons@curtin.edu.au
Renata Ferreira Barros d
renataferbar@gmail.com
a Postgraduate Program of the Institute of Geosciences (IGc), University of São Paulo, 562, Rua do Lago, 05508-080, São Paulo, Brazil
b School of Earth and Planetary Sciences, The Institute of Geoscience Research (TIGeR), Curtin University, GPO Box U1987, Perth, WA 6845, Australia
c Institute of Geosciences (IGc), University of São Paulo, 562, Rua do Lago, 05508-080, São Paulo, Brazil
d School of Earth Science, University College Dublin, Belfield, Dublin 4, Ireland
ABSTRACT
A large slice of continental lower crust outcrops in the southernmost Brasília Orogen,
Brazil, where rocks were metamorphized at UHT conditions in the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe. The
metamorphic rocks there have a long history of melt crystallization between 630 and 595 Ma, and
several granitic bodies were generated, including charnockites, which present same ages of
crystallization. One of this charnockite suite, Paraguaçu Suite (c. 630 to 611 Ma), is subdivided in
two bodies, north and south, and presents intermediate composition with high #Mg, Ba, Zr, Hf and
REE contents and depleted in Sr, Th and U, suggesting a depleted source that K-feldspar, zircon
and garnet were been molten. Metamorphic modelling performed in a felsic granulite, from
Granulitic Unit, shows that K-feldspar, zircon and garnet were broken during the UHT stage and
the melt generated has similar trends of major elements as those found in Paraguaçu Suite.
However, Paraguaçu Suite has higher Na2O contents and lower SiO2 than what is predicted in the
partial melting granulite model. Thus, it is likely that the migration and crystallization of the felsic
granulite partial melting was the major source for the generation of Paraguaçu Suite, and mixture
with other source(s), probably more radiogenic, evidenced by a least negative ?Hf in zircon in the
north body, which also is enriched in Sr and Ti. The mixture with radiogenic sources and the
radioactive decay of a large volume of partial melt generated in this segment of Socorro-Guaxupé
Nappe were the responsibles to the heating to UHT conditions.
101
Keywords: Charnockite source, heat source, phase equilibrium modelling, U-Pb geochronology,
Hf isotope, Nd isotope, Brasília Orogen
INTRODUCTION
The granitic magmatism is one of the most important process of formation and recycling
of the continental crust, particularly during orogenic events, resulting in the geochemistry
differentiation of the crust since the Archean (Brown, 2001). The chemical composition of the
resulting magma depends on the composition of sources and the extent of partial melting (Faure,
1998). Therefore, a geochemical study of the igneous rocks provides insights of their sources,
being a classical approach to reveal process and sources of the magmas (e.g. Brown et al. 1984;
Pearce et al. 1984; Pearce 1996; Janasi 2002; Alves et al. 2016).
A new approach to investigate partial melting and magma formation counts with the
recent development of the activity-composition models for tonalite–trondhjemite melt
compositions (Green et al., 2016), which combined with thermodynamics of minerals end-
member properties (Powell and Holland, 1988), allowing to access and model process of crust
formation and differentiation (e.g. Holland et al., 2018; Palin et al., 2016), including how the first
continental crust was formed and stabilized (Johnson et al., 2017). Thus, now it is possible do the
reverse path, i.e., access the product composition via the thermodynamic modelling of the source.
The present work uses this new approach to retrieve the source of the charnockite
magmatism in the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe, southernmost Brasília Orogen, in Brazil, using
thermodynamic equilibria modelling, via THERMOCALC (Powell et al., 1998) coupled with
accessory mineral behaviour (Kelsey et al., 2008). It combines isotopic and elemental
geochemistry of whole rock and zircon geochronology.
GEOLOGICAL BACKGROUND
The Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe is an allochtonous high-grade metamorphic terrane, with
granulites, migmatites and granitic rocks in a horizontal stack of nappes that were formed during
the Neoproterozoic (~ 640–600 Ma), in the southernmost Brasília Orogen, at the southwestern
border of the São Francisco Craton. It represents a magmatic arc setting that developed in a
continental active margin at Paranapanema Plate (Brito Neves et al., 1999; Campos Neto et al.,
2011; Campos Neto and Caby, 2000, 1999).
The Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe shows a right-way-up crustal section of hot and partially
melted layered crust and is lithologically subdivided into: (1) Metatexite on top; (2) Diatexite in
intermediate; and (3) Granulite on its base (Campos Neto and Caby, 2000). The structure is
segmented into two domains (Del Lama et al., 2000; Janasi, 2002), which high-angle lateral ramps
102
are developed: Guaxupé Domain in the northwestern where granulites and diatexites are
dominant (Fig. 1), and Socorro Domain in southeastern where metatexites are dominant.
Fig. 1. (A) The southernmost Brasilia Orogen and its relation with Neoproterozoic Cratons. (B) Geological framework of the Guaxupé Domain, in which the three charnockite suites are highlighted in shades of red (modified after Campos Neto et al. 2010).
The Guaxupé Domain records high to ultra-high temperature (UHT) of metamorphism.
Thermobarometric studies of granulites show a range in T conditions above 800 °C, and
sometimes reaching 1000 °C (Campos Neto and Caby, 2000; Del Lama et al., 1998, 1994; Iyer et
al., 1996; Rocha et al., 2018, 2017; Tedeschi, 2018). The heat that produced the metamorphism
103
was able also to generate large volumes of magma. Among several felsic intrusions three suites
stand out due to their anhydrous character: Divinolândia, São Pedro de Caldas (Janasi, 2002, 1999,
1997) and Paraguaçu (Barros, 2012).
The Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe has sinuous edges lying above the passive margin
assemblage and the Andrelândia Nappe System, which are composed by metassedimentary rocks
metamorphosed at high-pressure conditions (Campos Neto et al., 2010; Campos Neto and Caby,
1999; Motta and Moraes, 2017).
Charnockites from Guaxupé Domain
The charnockite bodies are intrusive in migmatites, which present different rates of partial
melting. Usually they have a semi-tabular shape parallel to the regional foliation. They also show
a solid-state foliation consistent to the regional structure. Two large suites, São Pedro de Caldas,
more felsic, and Divinolândia, were detailed by Janasi (1999; 2002) and present contrasting
features.
São Pedro de Caldas Suite is composed by orthopyroxene monzonite, which has a
compositional continuum with leucogranite. This suite has a low color indices (8-15) and quartz
contents between 5 and 15 vol.% (Janasi, 2002).
Divinolândia Suite presents coarse-grained orthopyroxene monzonite, with minor
amount of orthopyroxene monzogranite and quartz syenite. In the orthopyroxene monzonite is
common the presence of enclaves of pyroxene diorites. The Divinolândia Suite has a higher color
indices (>12-15), lower quartz contents and slightly more plagioclase than São Pedro de Caldas
Suite (Janasi, 2002, 1999).
PARAGUAÇU SUITE
The Paraguaçu Suite presents medium- to coarse-grained green charnockites with a
quartz syenite composition. It is composed of two bodies, both elongated N-S, intrusive in the
Diatexite Unit (Fig. 2A), although sometimes the contacts are parallelized with the regional
foliation (Fig. 2B). Actually, the foliation occurs throughout the bodies, parallel to the regional
main foliation, partially obliterating original igneous textures.
Rocks from Paraguaçu Suite has quartz-monzonite to quartz-syenite compositions.
Perthitic to mesoperthitic K-feldspar and homogeneous oligoclase are the main felsic minerals. As
mentioned, the matrix exhibits deformational fabric, with a granoblastic texture, although some
feldspar phenocrysts are preserved (Fig. 2C). The exsolutions in K-feldspar are often concentrated
in the core of the crystals, with clean rims (Fig. 2D). The occurrence of orthopyroxene is
widespread all over the bodies reaching up to 5% in modal volume (Fig. 2E). Hornblende is the
main mafic mineral and occurs as phenocrysts (Fig. 2B), although sometimes it appears
104
surrounding orthopyroxene (Fig. 2F). Clinopyroxene is subordinate and when present has
exsolution lamellae of clinoenstatite (Fig. 2G). Biotite is scarce to absent. The Fe-Ti oxides are
ilmenite and magnetite and the most abundant accessory minerals, occurring as irregular-shaped
aggregates to prismatic crystals. Zircon is abundant and forms large prismatic crystals, as well as
apatite (Fig. 2F).
Fig. 2. (A) Intrusive contact between the charnockite and the diatexite generating some mixture zones (RGM54). (B) Parallelized contacts with the main foliation between the charnockite and diatexite and phenocrysts of hornblende in the charnockite (RGM57) – both in (A) and (B) the rule has 30 cm. (C) Granular to granoblastic fabric in the matrix, and the preservation of K-feldspar phenocrysts in the charnockite (PAR40). (D) Perthitic K-feldspar with coarsed exsolutions lamellae of plagioclase in the core and clear rim (PAR32C). (E) Cluster of orthopyroxene parallel to the main foliation surrounding by hornblende (RGM53). (F) Cluster of hornblende wrapping an orthopyroxene grain and huge crystals of accessory phases, such as apatite and zircon (PAR40). (G) Orthopyroxene lamellae hosted in a clinopyroxene crystal (PAR32C).
Elemental geochemistry
Whole-rock major and trace element composition of studied rocks are presented in
ANEXO VI. Analytical procedures are described in Appendix A.
The rocks from Paraguaçu Suite present a narrow range of SiO2, between 60.33 and 62.75
wt.% (Fig. 3). They show a negative correlation between SiO2 and FeO, MgO and CaO (Fig. 3A to
C), whereas positive with Na2O and Al2O3 (Fig. 3E to F). The #Mg varies between 18 and 25 and
show negative correlation with SiO2. The contents of major elements are intermediate to the other
charnockite suites, which in general present negative correlation in Hacker diagrams against SiO2.
105
Fig. 3. Behaviour of major elements against SiO2 in the charnockites of Guaxupé Domain. The granulite partial melting composition calculated in THERMOCALC are also shown. (*) São Pedro de Caldas and Divinolândia Suites data extracted from Janasi (2002).
The REE patterns in the Paraguaçu Suite (Fig. 4) present a large range of fractionation
(LaN/YbN = 10.4 – 35.4, with 2nd quartile at 12.34), with more degree related to LREE (LaN/SmN =
2.37 – 6.40), which is 40 to 300 times richer than chondrites. The HREE are slightly less
fractionated (GdN/YbN = 2.10 – 3.05) and are 4 to 30 times richer than chondrite. There is a narrow
range of Eu concentration, with anomalies varying from positive to slightly negative (Eu/Eu* =
0.77 – 2.06). REE contents, in Paraguaçu Suite, mostly overlap the other charnockite suites,
although sometimes the REE contents are slightly depleted.
Fig. 4. Chondrite normalized REE patterns for Paraguaçu Suite (this work), São Pedro de Caldas Suite and Divinolândia Suite (both are data compiled from Janasi, 2002).
106
U-Pb geochronology and zircon composition
Zircon crystals from four samples were analyzed (RGM02, 04, 53 and 57). Analytical
procedures are described in Appendix A. Data are presented in ANEXO VIII and ANEXO X.
In all samples, the zircon crystals present similar shapes. They are prismatic, with
elongation ratios ranging 1:3 or 1:4 and, sometimes, doubly terminated. Their cores often have
dark CL features showing oscillatory to truncated internal zoning. Convoluted zones give the
transitions to the rims, which show no zoning or sector zoning and its response to CL is bright
(Fig. 5).
The distribution of dates shows the same pattern for all samples. A histogram of dates
shows a peak of data between 630 and 615 Ma, with a skewed pattern toward younger dates, until
dates<600 Ma (Fig. 6). Generally, older dates are related to cores and younger to rims, although
some grains yielded the same date even bearing different textures (Fig. 5). Younger dates are also
direct related to a decrease in the Th/U ratio (Fig. 6), which is always higher than 0.1.
Fig. 5. CL images of representative zircon grains from Paraguaçu Suite. Spot ID are labelled in black; the yellow ellipse shows the location of SHRIMP spot (~ 20 µm) and respective 206Pb/238U ages (Ma) are also labelled in yellow; the blue circle shows the location of LA-ICP-MS spot (~ 50 µm) and respective ?Hf(t) are labelled in blue. (A) RGM02; (B) RGM04; (C) RGM53; (D) RGM57.
Sample RGM02 has the largest spreading in 206Pb/238U spot dates, ranging from 639 ± 10
Ma to 557 ± 28 Ma (1? uncertainty – Fig. 6A) and a sharp trend of increasing of Th/U ratio to older
dates (Fig. 6C). Excluding dates from the skew, this sample yielded a weighted mean 206Pb/238U
date of 622 ± 6.8 Ma (Fig. 6B).
107
Fig. 6. U-Th-Pb zircon data. 206Pb/238U ages distribution for samples RGM02, 04, 53 and 57, respectively in (A), (D), (G) and (J), in which they generally show a long tail toward younger ages. Concordia diagrams (2? error ellipses) for samples: RGM02 (B), which yielded 622 ± 2.8 Ma (red ellipses were rejected from the calculations); RGM04 (E), which presented two populations (630.3 ± 2.9 Ma in black and 602.5 ± 3.5 Ma in red); RGM53 (H), which yielded 619.6 ± 5.8 Ma; and RGM57 (L), which yielded 611.4 ± 4.8 Ma (red ellipses were rejected from the calculations). Th/U ratios against 206Pb/238U ages for samples RGM02, 04, 53 and 57, respectively in (C), (F), (I) and (K), in which they generally exhibit a positive slope.
Sample RGM04 shows two peak of 206Pb/238U spot dates (Fig. 6D). The oldest peak yielded
weighted mean 206Pb/238U of 630.3 ± 2.9 Ma, whereas the youngest peak provided 602.5 ± 3.5 Ma
(Fig. 6E). Overall, the youngest group has a more spread and lower values of Th/U ratios
compared to the oldest group of dates (Fig. 6F).
Sample RGM53 has a more symmetric spread in 206Pb/238U spot dates (Fig. 6G), although
they are more concentrated, ranging from 604 ± 11 Ma to 638 ± 12 Ma (1? uncertainty). Data gave
108
a weighted mean 206Pb/238U date of 619.6 ± 5.8 Ma (Fig. 6H). There is no pattern related to the
Th/U ratios (Fig. 6I).
Sample RGM57, the only located in the north body, shows 206Pb/238U spot dates among
588 ± 9 Ma and 641 ± 9 Ma (1? uncertainty – Fig. 6J). The zircon rims in this sample are the well
developed (Fig. 5). The weighted mean 206Pb/238U date of the peak in the histogram is the youngest
among the samples, yielding 611.4 ± 4.8 Ma (Fig. 6K). The same trend of decreasing of Th/U ratios
toward younger dates is observed (Fig. 6L).
The zircon grains from all samples have similar composition of REE (Fig. 7). They present
a spread pattern in LREE, with Ce anomalies varying from strongly positive to weakly negative
(Ce/Ce* = 0.74 – 111.67). The MREE is characterized by enrichment in relation to chondrite, with
a negative Eu anomaly. The HREE pattern shows a steep enrichment toward Lu.
Fig. 7. REE patterns of zircon crystals, chondrite normalized (Sun and McDonough, 1989) of Paraguaçu Suite. (A) RGM02, (B) RGM04, (C) RGM53 and (D) RGM57.
Isotopic geochemistry
Nd and Sr signatures
The Sr and Nd isotopic compositions of six samples are reported in ANEXO VII, and
analytical procedures are described in Appendix A. All analyzed samples are from southern body.
Model ages and ?Nd values were calculated using GCDkit software (Janoušek et al., 2006) and they
were set for 620 Ma (further information see discussions bellow).
The Sr and Nd parameters are very homogeneous among the samples. 87Sr/86Sri ratio
ranges from 0.7095 to 0.7101 (Fig. 8A), ?Ndt is negative, ranging between -11.8 and -12.4, and the
Nd TDM varies from 2.20 to 2.32 Ga (Fig. 8B).
109
Fig. 8. ?Nd versus 87Sr/86Sr (at 619 Ma) in (A) and versus model ages from depleted mantle (DM) and chondritic uniform reservoir (CHUR) in (B). Triangules in (A) are data from Paraguçu Suite. São Pedro Caldas and Divinolândia Suites from Janasi (2002).
Hf signature in zircon
Analytical techniques are described in Appendix A and the data are available in ANEXO XI.
The same samples and spots in zircon grains from SHRIMP were used to analyze Lu and Hf
isotopes and, although U-Pb data were acquired by LASS-ICP-MS, the 206Pb/238U spot age obtained
in SHRIMP was used as reference.
Zircon from all samples has similar 176Lu/177Hf ratios (Fig. 9B). The samples from the south
body (RGM02, 04 and 53) have similar ?Hft (between -16.1 and -12.6 – Fig. 9A). On the other hand,
the sample from the north body (RGM57), presents the least negative ?Hft (between -10.6 and -
8.0 – Fig. 9A), hence the highest 176Hf/177Hf ratio values (Fig. 9B).
Fig. 9. Zircon isotopic composition. (A) ?Hf against 206Pb/238U ages (Ma). (B) 176Hf/177Hf against Log 176Lu/177Hf.
GRANULITES FROM GUAXUPÉ DOMAIN
The granulites in Guaxupé Domain have a multiple sorts of protoliths, such as pelites and
mafic rocks, although felsic igneous rocks dominate it (Motta et al., n.d.). The ultra-high
temperature conditions (UHT) for the metamorphism, T > 900 °C, are widespread (Del Lama et
110
al., 1994; Rocha, 2016; Tedeschi, 2018). Mafic granulites have a little compositional variability
(Del Lama et al., 1998), and they are made of clinopyroxene, orthopyroxene, plagioclase, and a
variable amounts of quartz, hornblende and biotite, which may be absent. Garnet is usually absent.
Pelitic granulite developed a high refractory residuum of garnet, sillimanite, rutile, spinel, biotite
and ilmenite, with a little amount of felsic phases, and leucosome of granitic composition is
widespread.
The felsic granulites are banded and composed by a monzogranitic leucosome and a
residuum of clinopyroxene, orthopyroxene, plagioclase, K-feldspar, quartz, ilmenite and
magnetite with variable amount of garnet, hornblende and biotite, which may be absent. This is
the dominant rock type among the basal portion of this domain.
Melt composition from partial melting of the garnet felsic granulite
Previous modelled pseudosections are used to constrain the melt composition generated
from partial melting of the garnet felsic granulite (Motta et al., n.d.). Calculations were conducted
with THERMOCALC, in a ten component chemical system Na2O-CaO-K2O-FeO-MgO-Al2O3-SiO2-
H2O-TiO2-O2 (NCKFMASHTO), and for further discussions regarding the pseudosections
modelling, check Motta et al. (n.d.). Accessory mineral behaviour is calculated following the
methodology of Kelsey et al. (2008). Melt compositions extract from THERMOCALC are combined
with the solubility expressions for zircon (Watson and Harrison, 1983) and apatite (Harrison and
Watson, 1984) to determine the saturation concentrations of Zr and P2O5. The data obtained were
gridded via interpolation and superimposed onto the calculated phase diagram. Stoichiometric
values of Zr in zircon were 497,644 ppm (Kelsey et al., 2008) and P2O5 in apatite were 41 wt. %
(Webster and Piccoli, 2015). It was assumed that all Zr and P2O5 are restricted to zircon and
apatite, respectively.
The garnet felsic granulite modelled by Motta et al. (n.d.) shows that the metamorphic
peak paragenesis, composed of clino- and orthopyroxene, garnet, K-feldspar, plagioclase, quartz,
ilmenite and leucosome was stable at temperatures between 880 and 1030 °C at pressures
between 9 and 12 kbar (Fig. 10A). The melt proportion, in these P-T conditions, is between 5 and
20 % (Fig. 10A). In the metamorphic peak conditions, around 1000 °C, at fixed pressure of 10 kbar,
K-feldspar and garnet were not been totally molten, but were decreasing their modal proportions
(Fig. 10B) and, at the same time, the residuum was increasing in plagioclase and orthopyroxene
proportions.
111
Fig. 10. Phase equilibria modelling of a garnet felsic granulite from Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe (after Motta et al., n.d.). (A) Calculated P-T pseudosection for the composition shown at the right-top of the figure (values in mol.%), in which the dashed lines represent the modal proportion of melt generated. (B) Changes in the modal proportion of phases at fixed pressure of 10 kbar. (C) Percentage of zircon dissolution relative to the amount at the solidus. (D) Percentage of apatite dissolution relative to the amount at the solidus.
A pressure of 10 kbar was set to constrain the composition of melt generated in a window
between 900 and 1050 °C. The melt generated by the model has composition in the threshold
between intermediate and acid range, as the content of SiO2 varies from 67.7 to 66.1% (Fig. 3),
being the more acid compositions related to lower temperature (900 °C). The behaviour of CaO,
FeOT, MgO predicted in the model show the same trends and contents than the rocks from
Paraguaçu Suite, with a decreasing to more fractionated compositions than observed in the
natural rocks (Fig. 3). Similar behaviour and content are observed in K2O, both show a positive
correlation with SiO2. The major difference between the modelled melt and the observed in
112
Paraguaçu Suite is the contents of Al2O3 and Na2O, in which both are depleted in the predicted
model, although their trends have the same positive slope against SiO2 (Fig. 3).
The curves of zircon dissolution are straight and strongly dependent on the temperature
(Fig. 10C). The proportion of dissolved zircon in the peak paragenesis field can reach 50%. Apatite
dissolution has similar behaviour, although the curves show a weakly negative slope in the fields
where garnet is not predicted to be stable and sharper temperature dependence in the fields
where garnet is predicted to be stable (Fig. 10D). The amount of apatite dissolved in the field of
the metamorphic peak assemblage can achieve 20 %. Therefore, even underwent UHT
metamorphism, the garnet felsic granulite residuum still had solid zircon and apatite and some of
these solid grains could be dragged into the generated melt and worked as xenocrysts and
contaminant.
DISCUSSION
Petrogenesis of Paraguaçu Suite
The thermodynamic modelling for the garnet felsic granulite shows that K-feldspar and
garnet were the major phases been consumed at metamorphic peak, as zircon and apatite were
the accessory phases been dissolved, while plagioclase and orthopyroxene were not. The
produced melt have similar composition as the charnockites from Paraguçu Suite, particularly in
relation to FeO, MgO, CaO, and K2O.
The study charnockites have content of Fe2O3 + MgO + MnO + TiO2 between 6 and 10%,
higher than those observed in experimental studies for typical anatetic granites (Patiño Douce
and Beard, 1995). Assuming a crustal source, the breakdown of biotite, a mineral rich in these
elements, can generate around 4.5% of Fe2O3 + MgO + MnO + TiO2. Due to the anhydrous character
of the magma and the high values of Fe2O3 + MgO + MnO + TiO2, it seems unlikely that the
charnockitic magma was generated by biotite dehydration reactions alone. Therefore, the high
values for the mentioned elements require an enriched source, in which, due to the high
temperature of formation, biotite were firstly consumed at lower temperatures (<900 °C), leaving
behind a garnet-rich residuum, enriched in Fe/Mg ratios, and then the dissolution of garnet, at
higher temperatures was responsible for melt enrichment in these elements. The high K/Rb and
the remarkable depletion in Cs, Th and U is typically attributed to residual sources (Fig. 11),
depleted in Rb by previous events of magma extraction, highlighting the residual character of the
source.
113
Fig. 11. Continental crust normalized (Wedepohl, 1995) incompatible element patterns.
There is a notable enrichment in Ba in the rocks of the Paraguaçu Suite (Fig. 11). Biotite
and K-feldspar are the mainly common Ba-bearing phases and, as previously mentioned, biotite
is not a good candidate to be present in the magma source, thus, the contribution of K-feldspar
must be important during UHT conditions. The composition of Paraguaçu Suite and the garnet
felsic granulite shows complementary content of Sr, element mainly held in calcic plagioclase,
with positive anomalies in the garnet felsic granulite and negative in the charnockite, except for
the sample located in the north body of the suite. Thus, it is likely that plagioclase was not
consumed in the source, which is also observed in the partial melt modeling of the granulite,
where plagioclase has been increase in modal proportion in the residuum at the metamorphic
peak conditions (Fig. 11), and supported by the low content of Ca in the charnockites. Thereby,
the enrichment in LREE and Eu in the anhydrous magma is related to the participation of K-
feldspar as a reactant in the melt reactions, a phase in granulite facies enriched patterns of LREE
and strongly positives Eu anomalies (Bea, 1996), as it is possible to observe by the decrease of the
modal proportion of the mineral in the modelling (Fig. 11). The north body of the Paraguaçu Suite
may have been enriched in Sr and Ca by contamination with other sources, probably plagioclase-
rich or represent a batch of melt enriched in plagioclase component, facilitated by a more fertile
portion of the source.
The behaviour of Zr and Hf between charnockites and granulites shows an inverse
relationship (Fig. 11), suggesting that zircon was dissolved in the source and concentrated in the
melt. Furthermore, the rocks from Paraguaçu Suite present high contents of HREE and Y and
moderated La/Yb ratios. These observations strengthen that zircon was dissolved in the source,
which is possible to observe in the modelling of the granulite partial melting, where up to 50% of
zircon has been dissolved at metamorphic peak conditions (Fig. 10C). The breakdown of garnet
may also increase the content of HREE, Y and the La/Yb ratio in the melt, which occurred during
the metamorphic peak in the granulites and their partial melting (Fig. 10B).
114
Ti-bearing phase, mainly ilmenite, is refractory, hence it tolerates or grows at high
temperatures. Positive anomalies in the granulites and negative in the charnockites (Fig. 11)
suggests that Ti-phases were not solubilized during the partial melting. The main Nb-bearing
phases are zircon and hornblende, apart from Ti-phases. The inverse behaviour of Nb between
charnockites and granulites is unlikely to be led by Ti-phases, therefore it may be related to
breakdown of hornblende, in an initial stage, and particularly to zircon solubilization in the
source. One problem to analyze the Ti-bearing phase behaviour during partial melting with
thermodynamic modelling is the melt models do not accept Ti dissolution and so, even if a portion
of ilmenite could be melted and dissolved in the melt in nature, it does stay solid in the modelling.
Thus, although the geochemical behaviour suggests that Ti-phases were not reactants in the
source, some of the conclusion of elements carried must be taken with caution.
The geochronology data obtained in zircon from Paraguaçu Suite shows a maximum
crystallization age from c. 630 to 619 Ma for the southern body and c. 611 Ma for the northern
body, with a spread toward younger ages until c. 600 Ma, in both bodies (Fig. 6). These dates are
coeval to the UHT metamorphism of the Granulitic Unit in the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe, where the
metamorphic peak to the final crystallization of the partial melting happened between 630 and
595 Ma (Rocha et al., 2018, 2017; Tedeschi, 2018). This time span of c. 35 Myr corresponds to the
magmatic residence time, which the oldest ages must be related to xenocrystals from the source
and/or autocrystals and the youngest ages may be related to a continuous input of melt coming
from the source. The age of c. 620 Ma is interpreted as the peak of the magmatism because the
majority of data are concentrated in this date. Therefore, the magmatic age of Paraguaçu Suite fits
the time when granulite metamorphism and partial melting were been happening in the Granulitic
Unit.
The decreasing of Th/U ratios in zircon toward younger ages (Fig. 6) and morphology of
the crystals (Fig. 5), in Paraguaçu Suite, features used to infer a slow crystallization of magma with
prolonged residence time in the lower crust (Corfu et al., 2003), as observed by the scatter of
dates, particularly toward the youngest ages. A large spread in LREE in zircon grains also suggests
a complex crystallization history, and the competition for these elements with feldspars.
Thus, the behaviour of major and incompatible elements follows complementary trends
between charnockites and granulites. Their ages are correspondent, including a prolonged record
of crystallization. It is unlikely that hydrated phases, particularly biotite, were present in the
sources of the anhydrous magma, particularly at UHT conditions. K-feldspar was partially
extracted from the source, as well as zircon, apatite and garnet, however, Ti-phases,
orthopyroxene and plagioclase were retained in the residuum. The geochemical data are
compatible with the calculated metamorphic modelling for the garnet felsic granulite. Lower
115
contents of SiO2 and Na2O in the charnockites than the melt generated from the garnet felsic
granulite modelling may indicate a mixture of other sources, probably with more mafic affinity. In
the field, it is common to observe lenses of mafic granulite, with or without garnet, within the
garnet felsic granulite, some of them bearing microscopic to centimetric lenses of leucosome,
which present a tonalite composition and would work as a source to deviate the modelled melt
composition into what is observed in nature. Another possibility is the mixture with basic magma
intruded into the column of granulites with source in the mantle, which is common and observed
in several outcrops in the region and coeval or a little younger than granulite facies
metamorphism (Rocha et al., 2018, 2017; Tedeschi, 2018).
Comparison between the charnockite suites
The three charnockites suites in the Guaxupé Domain, Divinolândia, São Pedro de Caldas
e Paraguaçu, show similar trends of distribution of major elements, being Divinolândia Suite the
less fractionated and São Pedro de Caldas the most, with Paraguaçu presenting intermediate
composition between them (Fig. 3). Divinolândia Suite has SiO2 content between 52.8 and 67.3
wt.%, while São Pedro de Caldas presents 61.5 and 78.1 wt.%. All suites are ferroan with
shoshonitic affinity (Fig. 12). The highest K/Rb ratio is observed in Paraguaçu Suite, whereas the
lowest is observed in São Pedro de Caldas Suite (Fig. 12).
Fig. 12. (A) #Fe (mol. FeOT/(FeOT+MgO) diagram showing the boundary between ferroan and magnesian plutons. (B) Potassium content based binary diagram showing magmatic series. (C) Ba/Sr ratio against K/Rb. (*) data from Janasi (2002)
The three charnockite suites in the Guaxupé Domain, Divinolândia, São Pedro de Caldas e
Paraguaçu, have the same fractionated pattern of REE, enriched in LREE (Fig. 4). Compared to the
others suites, Paraguaçu Suite shows depletion in REE, particularly compared to São Pedro de
Caldas Suite (Fig. 4).
Although there are no in situ geochronologic data for Divinolândia and São Pedro de
Caldas Suite, the ages of crystallization are also similar among them. U-Pb zircon data for
Divinolândia Suite indicated crystallization age of 625 ± 7 Ma, by conventional TIMS (Basei et al.,
1995). Also by conventional TIMS, Janasi (2002) dated zircon fractions from São Pedro de Caldas
Suite and obtained age of 623.3 ± 3.1 Ma, although one fraction of crystals yielded younger Pb-Pb
116
date of 607 ± 8 Ma. All this dates are similar to obtained in this work for Paraguaçu Suite, which
means that the charnockite magmatism in Guaxupé Domain was coeval.
Although there are many similarities among the charnockite suites, it is unlikely that they
had the same source. Janasi (2002) suggests that São Pedro de Caldas Suite was formed by melting
of a fertile granulite crust, which generated large volumes of magma, whereas Divinolândia Suite
may derivate from a more refractory granulite with incorporation of basic magma with calc-
alkaline affinities. Paraguaçu Suite is extremely depleted in Rb related to the other suites, and as
previously discussed, may originated by a single source, the partial melting of the garnet felsic
granulite, with a minor contribution of mafic components.
The origin of the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe
The whole rock isotopic data point out to a long crustal residence for the three suites (Fig.
8). São Pedro de Caldas has the least negative ?Ndt values (-3 to -6) and Divilolândia Suite has the
most scattered values (-9 to -14). This implies to younger TDM ages in São Pedro de Caldas (1.2 to
1.6 Ga) than Divinolândia Suite (1.8 to 2.3 Ga) (Janasi, 2002). Paraguaçu Suite has the most
homogeneous data with ?Ndt between -11,8 and -12,4 and TDM between 2.2 and 2.3 Ga,
representing the oldest model ages.
The isotopic Hf data in zircon crystals from Paraguaçu Suite leads to the same
interpretation of long crustal residence. The ?Hft is always negative and homogeneous, between -
8 and -10.6 in the north body and -12.6 and -16 in the south body. An event signature diagram
(Fig. 13) is a useful tool that shows the input of juveline material relative to crustal reworking
(Belousova et al., 2009). The x-axis is the crystallization age (Ma) obtained by U-Pb in SHRIMP and
the y-axis represents the crustal residence of the material (Ma), obtained by the crystallization
age minus the Lu-Hf model age. The Paraguaçu Suite shows a near horizontal trend with a weak
diagonally downward trending, which represents a mixing between reworked crustal segments
and juveline additions (Fig. 13).
117
Fig. 13. Evolution signature of the charnockites from Paraguaçu Suite, typical from a collision, in which is influenced by a mixed juvenile and reworked sources as oceanic tract closes with volcanic arcs and terranes being accreted.
Although the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe is considered to be formed in a magmatic arc setting
(Campos Neto and Caby, 1999; Mora et al., 2014; Rocha et al., 2018), juvenile rocks have not been
recognized here or in other portions of the nappe (Campos Neto et al., 2011; Janasi, 2002; Mora et
al., 2014; Rocha et al., 2018; Tedeschi, 2018). In general, two factors can be responsible for this
isotopic signature: contamination and assimilation of crustal basement (e.g. Schoene et al., 2009)
and/or a mixing between enriched lithospheric mantle and crustal components (e.g. Hagen-Peter
et al., 2015).
There are only a few data showing inheritance in zircon cores with ages to the probable
basement of the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe, concentrated in 2.5 Ga and possibly related to rocks of
the Paranapanema Craton (Tedeschi et al., 2018), as the ages related to São Francisco Craton are
scattered from the Paleoproterozoic, c. 2.08 Ga, (e.g. Cioffi et al. 2016b) to the Mesoarchean, c. 3.0
Ga (e.g. Cioffi et al. 2016a). In addition, the model ages, either Nd or Hf, aim to dates older than 1.2
Ga, in which many of them are older than 2.0 Ga. Thus, if this process of assimilation happened, a
great amount of basement would have participated and it would be expected a higher volume of
data of inheritance from the basement. Therefore, the contamination/assimilation of basement
might have played a minor role in the formation of the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe.
The absence of juveline rocks has been attributed to a mixing with enriched mantle
(Carvalho et al., 2014; Janasi, 2002; Mora et al., 2014; Rocha et al., 2018). This interpretation is
well supported by the shoshonitic affinity of the rocks in the segment and the presence of high-
pressure metassedimentary rocks in the Andrelândia Nappes System (Campos Neto et al., 2010;
Campos Neto and Caby, 2000; Frugis et al., 2018; Motta and Moraes, 2017; Tedeschi et al., 2017)
that reached mantle depths and may have contributed to the metassomatism.
Nevertheless, the long crustal histories printed in the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe rocks raise
doubts about its origin. In the typical region of the southern Brasília Orogen, the magmatic arc
domain, represented by Arenópolis Arc (Fig. 14), is composed by calc-alkaline plutonic rocks, with
118
variable degrees of deformation and metamorphism, and supracrustal sequences, comprising
metavolcanic and immature metasedimentary rocks (Pimentel, 2016; Pimentel et al., 2011). The
magmatism event started in c. 900 Ma lasting until 640 Ma (Laux et al., 2005), with juvenile
signatures, marked by positive to weakly negative ?Nd values (Laux et al., 2005; Pimentel et al.,
1996; Pimentel and Fuck, 1992). These features agree with data from Mara Rosa Arc (Pimentel,
2016), the magmatic arc domain in the northern Brasília Orogen (Fig. 14), but do not match with
those found in Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe.
Other than that, in the typical region of the southern Brasília Orogen, the Anápolis-Itauçu
Complex (Fig. 14) presents similar rock association as Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe, with granulites
derived from igneous protoliths, such as tonalite and granodiorite, and sedimentary rocks, with
granite and layered gabbro intrusions (Moraes et al., 2004). U–Pb zircon ages are spread between
760 and 650 Ma and interpreted as magmatic activity (Piuzana et al., 2003a), while
metamorphism is recorded between 650 and 630 Ma (Baldwin and Brown, 2008; Della Giustina
et al., 2011; Piuzana et al., 2003b) and reached UHT conditions (Baldwin et al., 2005; Moraes et
al., 2002). Isotopic signatures show negative ?Nd values, between -9.3 and -1.4, and Nd model ages
fall into two intervals, between 2.3–1.9 Ga and 1.7–1.4 Ga (Piuzana et al., 2003a). Anápolis-Itauçu
Complex is interpreted as the metamorphic core of Brasília Orogen (Della Giustina et al., 2009;
Fuck et al., 1994; Pimentel, 2016). Geographically, Arenópolis Arc is exposed to the west of
Anápolis-Itauçu Complex and eastward Araxá Group, a metassedimentary sequence, outcrops
(Fig. 14).
Rock associations, magmatic ages, metamorphic ages and conditions and isotopic
signatures of Anápolis-Itauçu Complex are very similar to the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe. The
western region of the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe is covered by a thick (dozens of kilometer) Paleo-
to Mesozoic sedimentary basin (Campos Neto and Caby, 2000), the Paraná Basin, and in the
northeastern-eastern it is limited by a metasedimentary domain, the Andrelândia Nappe System
(Fig. 1 and Fig. 14). Thus, instead of Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe being the magmatic arc it seems that
it is related to the metamorphic core of the southernmost Brasília Orogen. Moreover, in the
evolution models of the orogeny, São Francisco Plate have subducted Paranapanema Plate (Frugis
et al., 2018; Motta and Moraes, 2017), thus the magmatic arc must be established in the latter.
Cioffi et al. (2016a, 2016b) linked a large portion of basement, which splits the Socorro-Guaxupé
Nappe into Guaxupé and Socorro Domain, to the São Francisco Craton, therefore the Socorro-
Guaxupé Nappe may be laid down above São Francisco Craton. Of course, this discussion is not
closed, and it just tries putting some lights into the issue.
119
Fig. 14. Overview of Brasília Orogen (Valeriano et al., 2004). External zone (1-4), in which: (1 and 2) Granite-greenstone terrains; 3 – Paleoproterozoic rift (Araí Group); (4) Ilicínea-Piumhi thrust system. Passive margin (5-8), in which: (5) Paranoá Group; (6) Quartzite-phyllite units (Canastra and Andrelândia groups); (7) Vazante Group; (8) Ibiá Group. Internal zone (9-14), in which: (9a and b) Araxá and Andralândia Groups; (10) Granulite nappes; (11 and 12) Archean/Paleoproterozoic gneiss and greenstone complex; (13) Mesoproterozoic volvano-sedimentary sequences (Juscelândia, Indaianópolis, Palmeirópolis); (14) Mafic-ultramafic complexes (Barro Alto, Niquelândia and Cana Brava). Goiás Magmatic Arc (15-16), in which: (15) Supracrustal sequences; (16) Orthogneisses and granitoids. MR – Mara Rosa Arc. AA – Arenópolis Arc. AI – Anápolis—Itauçu Complex. GD – Guaxupé Domain (Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe). SD – Socorro Domain (Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe).
The heat source to generated (ultra)-high temperatures
There is an agreement that UHT conditions occur in many metamorphic orogens, although
the heat source of such extreme temperatures (> 900 °C) is not well understood (Brown, 2007;
120
Clark et al., 2011; Harley, 1998; Kelsey and Hand, 2015). This because the lower continental crust
has low thermal diffusivity (Whittington et al., 2009), thus large amounts of energy are required
to elevate the temperature, whereas, once they have reached high temperatures, they tend to be
heated for a prolonged period (Kelsey and Hand, 2015). Furthermore, the generation of anatectic
melt hinder the temperature elevation, because partial meting reactions are endothermic
(Lyubetskaya and Ague, 2009), thus buffering the temperature (Stüwe, 1995). A great amount of
melt must be generated and drained from its source, thus the temperature can rise, and therefore
the rock is “pre-conditioned” to achieve such temperatures (Clark et al., 2011; Kelsey and Hand,
2015; Vielzeuf et al., 1990).
As previously discussed, it is unlikely biotite had a significant contribution to the
generation of the charnockites. Therefore, the partial melt generated by hydrate-phases
breakdown was formerly extracted. In addition, the partial melting in the Granulitic Unit of the
Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe was controlled by the breakdown of K-feldspar and garnet. Thus, it is
likely that rocks from the Granulitic Unit had reduced fertility (i.e. pre-conditioned), hence more
prone to heat at UHT conditions.
Three main factors are responsible to increase the temperature of the continental crust:
(1) radioactive heat production by decay of Th, U and, mainly, K (Alessio et al., 2018; England and
Thompson, 1984; Jamieson et al., 1998; Vilà et al., 2010); (2) mechanical heating in shear zones
(Nabelek et al., 2010); (3) advective mantle heat (Brown, 1993; Ellis, 1987; Vielzeuf et al., 1990).
The Diatexite Unit lies down the Granulite Unit in the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe, in which
significant amount of silicate melt were generated during the orogenesis, with an extension of
hundreds of km2 and ~ 9 km thick (Campos Neto and Caby, 1999). The rocks from both Diatexite
and Granulite Units present shoshonitic compositions (Janasi, 2002, 1999; Mora et al., 2014;
Rocha et al., 2018), hence enriched in potassium. Such expressive volume of radiogenic material
in the mid crust can elevate considerably the temperature in the lower crust (Gerya et al., 2008;
Jamieson et al., 2004). Accordingly, the very generation of partial melt and the subsequent
migration to higher levels in the crust played a major role to the heating of the orogen.
Compare to the south body, the north body of Paraguaçu Suite presents enrichment in Sr,
and higher values of ?Hf, up to + 4 ? units greater. These enrichments suggest a mix with other
source(s), more radiogenic (i.e. richer in 176Hf), in which plagioclase and Ti-phases were being
molten in the source, which is compatible with mafic sources. Moreover, compare to the modelled
melt composition, the Paraguaçu Suite is depleted in SiO2 and enriched in Na2O, another
suggestion that depleted sources have contributed in the generation of these magmas, and hence
to the heating in the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe, as suggested before due to interactions with mantle
derived material (Janasi, 2002; Rocha et al., 2018). Thus, small bodies of mafic rocks, now
121
recognized as mafic granulites, some preserving intrusive contacts, indicates a mantle
contribution to the base of this crust, and this may implies decompression of asthenospheric
mantle, which might worked as an additional heat source for metamorphism and some of these
basic bodies, as suggested in some models (Brown, 1993; Ellis, 1987).
CONCLUSIONS
The combination of data and methods used in this work have allowed concluding that:
? Paraguaçu Suite had a source in which K-feldspar, garnet, apatite and zircon were partially
solubilized;
? The garnet felsic granulite modelling shows K-feldspar, garnet and zircon were been
broken during the UHT stage;
? The composition of the modelled partial melt of a garnet felsic granulite show
complementarities with the composition of charnockites in Paraguaçu Suite;
? The ages of the charnockitic magmatism of Paraguaçu Suite and the UHT conditions in the
Granulitic Unit of Guaxupé Domain were the same, from c. 630 Ma scattered until c. 600
Ma, with concentration in c. 620 Ma.
Thus, the partial melting of the garnet felsic granulite may have migrated, collected,
concentrated and then generated the Paraguaçu Suite.
Futhermore, the charnockite magmatism in Guaxupé Domain are coeval, although the
three identified suites, Divinolândia, São Pedro de Caldas and Paraguaçu Suites, have different
sources or degrees of mixture/fractionation.
The heat source to generate UHT conditions in Guaxupé Domain is related to a radioactive
decay of a thick layer of molten rock that occurs above the Granulitic Unit add up with an input of
heat from the asthenospheric mantle.
